sect1.title: Image Export
sect1.para:
Microscopy data often need to rendered into image formats, usually for presentation purposes, occasionally to open them in programs that do not support any SPM data formats. Both is achieved the same way in Gwyddion: by selecting
File Save As
and choosing a file name corresponding to an image format, e.g. channel.png or channel.tiff. The reference section High-Depth Image Formats describes the export of data as high-depth greyscale images that should be still usable as quantiative data. For supported formats you can enabled it using the Export as 16 bit grayscale check-box at the top of the image export dialog. The rest of this section discusses the creation of nice images for publications and presentations.

Gwyddion can render images into a number of formats, including for instance PNG, PDF, SVG, EPS, TIFF, BMP, PPM, TARGA and JPEG. Depending on the intent, some may be more suitable more than others. Generally, the following choices can be recommended:

itemizedlist.listitem: PDF (Portable Document Format) for high-quality rendering suitable for printing, with all text and lines perfectly sharp and clean at any scale. Gwyddion also suports output to EPS (Encapsulated PostScript) for the same purpose, however, some features currently seem to work better in the PDF output.

PNG (Portable Network Graphics) for web pages, low-resolution previews, thumbnails and icons, and also if you have to use a raster image format because it is the only option. PNG is a modern and widely supported raster image format with good loseless compression and a number of nifty features.

SVG (Scalable Vector Graphics) for subsequent editing and processing. SVG is a modern vector graphics format. You can open in a vector image editor such as Inkscape and modify it or combine with other images â€“ keeping all text and lines perfectly sharp and clean.

sect1.para: The image export options are divided into several groups, as seen in the above screenshot.

sect2.title: Basic
sect2.para: Basic options specify various overall sizes and scales. The Physical Dimensions part differs for raster and vector images. For raster images the physical dimensions are specified as follows:

listitem.para: Scaling of data pixels to image pixels. The default zoom 1 means data pixels correspond exactly to image pixels. Upscaling is possible with zoom larger than 1, and downscaling with zoom smaller than 1. For data with non-square pixels displayed with physical aspect ratio, the zoom is applied to the shorted side of the pixel, whichever it is.
Width of the rectangle corresponding to data in the exported image (not width of the entire image), in pixels.
Height of the rectangle corresponding to data in the exported image (not height of the entire image), in pixels.

sect2.para: Vector images do not have finite pixel resolution, therefore, the physical dimensions can be instead given as follows:

listitem.para: Size of one data pixel in millimetres.
Number of data pixels per one inch.
Width of the rectangle corresponding to data in the exported image (not width of the entire image), in millimetres.
Height of the rectangle corresponding to data in the exported image (not height of the entire image), in millimetres.

mediaobject.caption: Illustration of the basic size parameters.

sect2.para: The remaining size and scale parameters, denoted Parameters, are common to both image types. However, for raster images they are in pixels while for vector images they are in typographical points. More precisely, this is true if they are given as absolute, i.e. the option Tie sizes to data pixels is not selected. If this option is selected all sizes are relative to data pixels, i.e. they scale together with the image data when the physical dimensions change. The parameters, illustrated in the figure above, include:

listitem.para: The font used to draw all labels.
Font size, in pixels or typographical points as described above.
Thickness of lines: borders, ticks, inset scale bar and selections.
Thickness of outlines that can be drawn around the inset scale bar and selections.
Width of empty border around the entire image.
Length of ruler and false colour map ticks. This setting also controls the inset scale bar ticks and crosses drawn for the point-like selection.

sect2.title: Lateral Scale
sect2.para: Settings in the Lateral Scale page control how the lateral dimensions are visualised. There are two basic choices displayed in the figure below, rulers and an inset scale bar, and the lateral scale information can be also disabled entirely. The inset scale bar has the following settings:

listitem.para: The length can be set manually to an arbitrary value which does not result in too short or too long bar. Press Enter to update the preview when you edit the length. Button Auto selects a suitable length automaticaly (this is also done when the manually entered length is not found reasonable).
The bar can be placed along the upper or lower edge and aligned to either side or centered.
Horizontal gap between the bar and the closer vertical edge of the data area (meaningful only if the bar is not centered).
Horizontal gap between the bar and the closer horizontal edge of the data area.
Color with which the bar is drawn. Buttons Black and White allow choosing quickly the basic colors.
Color of the outlines. Note if the outline width is zero (the default), no outlines are drawn, hence changing the color has no effect.
Opacity with which the inset scale bar is drawn. This settings permits drawing the bar as semi-transparent.
If enabled, the bar has vertical ticks at its ends. When disabled, the bar is just a line.
If enabled, the bar length is displayed under the bar.

sect2.title: Value
sect2.para: Settings in the Value page control the rendering of values and false colour mapping.

mediaobject.caption: Illustration of the various gap settings (for channel title, in the position at the top).

Rendering of the false color map scale depending on the mapping type. For the standard linear mapping, whether full or fixed range, ticks with values are drawn. For an adaptive mapping the color gradient is drawn the same, but tick positions correspond to the adaptive mapping and interior ticks are drawn without labels (to avoid overlapping labels). If a presentation is shown, the values are considered scaled arbitrarily thus no values and interior ticks are displayed.
